description.narrative: The overall objective of the proposed project is to bring long-term stability to communities in Darfur, through strengthening the support of sustainable peace dialogue mechanisms and capacities.

participating-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

1.1 : 10 CBRMs functioning 1.2: 95% community members 1.3 : 85% community members 1.4: 100% of cases 1.5 : 80% community members 1.6 : 85% community members 1.7 : 98% CBRMs 1.8 : 40% CBRM members 1.9 : 40% CBRM members 2.1: 30 2.2: 3 markets 2.3: Achieved in 2018 2.4: 70% of community members 2.5: 30% of community members 3.1: 10 JMC 3.2: 16 (3 veterinary centers +3 boreholes + 9 hand dug wells + 1 Peace Centre) cumulatively) 3.3: 75% community members stating an increase in the number of interactions 4.1: Additional 3 civil society organizations develop capacity to prioritize, plan, design and implement projects 4.2: Additional 3 civil society organizations 4.3: Additional 4 collective interactions

1.1 : 10 CBRMs functioning - It is following up of last year 10 CBRMs those reactivated 7 of them and 3 were newly formed 1.2: 100% community members reporting functioning CBRMs - All 10 CBRMs established/reactivated last year are functioning very well. From January to June 2019, the CBRMs received 145 cases. Out of the number of cases reported, 119 dispute cases were resolved representing 82%. Twenty-six (26) cases were transferred to the court. 1.3 : Perception survey to be conducted in December 2019 1.4: Perception survey to be conducted in December 2019 1.5 : 82% community members - 145 cases submitted to 10 CBRMs during January to June 2019. 119 out of 145 cases were resolved representing 82%. 26 cases transferred to the formal court system. Cases transferred to the court were on land disputes and looting assets and livestock. 1.6 : Perception survey to be conducted in December 2019 1.7 : Perception survey to be conducted in December 2019 1.8 : Perception survey to be conducted in December 2019 1.9 : Perception survey to be conducted in December 2019 2.1: 10 VSL Groups - To date, the total saving amount across 10 groups has reached SDG 78,660 with an average saving per group ranging between SDG 3,600 to SDG 17,800. More than SDG 19,300 has been given out as loans to group members to expand their business operations. 2.2: 3 markets - established 2 in Um Dukhun locality in Karakara and Selele and 1 in Dambar village -Mukjar locality. The market stalls were handed over to a market committee in each location where they allocated spaces for women; 60% of the spaces allocated to women 2.3: Achieved in 2018 2.4: Subject to Perception survey 2.5: Subject to Perception survey 3.1: 4 Joint Management Committees have been set up to coordinate the use of the assets created – 1 Peace Centre, 3 markets and 3 veterinary Centres. 3.2: 16 (3 veterinary centers +3 boreholes + 9 hand dug wells + 1 Peace Centre) cumulatively) 3.3: Subjected to Perception survey 4.1: Additional 3 civil society organizations develop capacity to prioritize, plan, design and implement projects 4.2: Additional 3 civil society organizations 4.3: Additional 4 collective interactions

5.1. 5 Field visits embarked: 5.2 One biannual report submitted in 2018 5.3 Five (5) technical Support visits paid to counterparts.

Results under Output 1: • Three (3) inception workshops organized in the three localities that created awareness among the targeted community members on the activities to be implemented. 400 Community members (300 male & 100 female) sensitized about the project in the entre 10 targeted villages • UNDP conducted two perception surveys in DCPSF project Operation areas within central Darfur, the finding of the two Surveys shown 80% of community members believed that trust and confidence has been restored between the two conflict parties Misseriya-Salamat conflict in Mukjar, Bindisi and Umm Dukhun localities. • The established 10 CBRM by the project are functioning very well. The CBRMs contribution represented in resolution and prevention platforms in Um Dukhun, Bindisi and Mukjar localities. 7 CBRMs reactivated and 3 new established and they received training on introduction to peacebuilding conflict resolution and mediation. • 57% of the community members were satisfied with the work of the CBRM in addressing and resolving disputes among communities as per perception survey. • 84% of cases submitted to CBRMs were successfully addressed and resolved at the CBRM level. During the two years lifecycle of the project a total of 359 disputes cases were brought to the attention of the CBRMs of which 305 represent 84% were resolved at the CBRM level. • 76% of community members starting decrease conflict. They strongly agreed that communal conflicts have decreased as a result of the presence of CBRM as reflected by the perception survey. • 100% of CBRMs members are actively participating in decision making. The project established 10 community-level conflict resolution and prevention platforms in Um Dukhun, Bindisi and Mukjar localities. • 40% of the CBRMs members are females. The project promoted the participation of female and youth in conflict resolution. The percentage of female in the CBRM committees increased from 10% to 40% • Participation of youth in the CBRMs increased from 14% to 30%.
Results under Output 2: • Ten Community-based participatory Planning (CBPP) conducted in 10 villages in conjunction with CBRMs. A total number of 100 CBRMs members (70 male & 30 female) actively participated in identify and review community needs, opportunities and priorities. Community development plans in targeted villages have been developed. The communities identified their needs and were able to explore new livelihood opportunities. • As per the result of perception survey 46% of community members are observing an increase in the economic interventions between diverse communities. • Three (3) markets have been constructed in the three localities, two markets in Um Dukuhn locality in karakara and Selele return villages and one in Dambar return village within Mukjar locality. UNDP and its partners supervised the handed over the market stalls to the communities, the space of each stall accommodated 40-women traders. • The project enhanced access to micro-credit through the establishment and training of ten (10) voluntary savings associations comprising 250 members (200 women and 50 men). The groups mobilized SDG 342,800 from the membership and advanced loans valued at SDG 212,700 to 170 of its members of whom 59% were women.
Results under Output 3: • 10 joint management committees (JMC) were established: four in Um Dukhun, three in Bendisi and three in Mukjar. Women and youth formed about 40% of the membership of the joint committees. • Twenty-seven social infrastructure projects have been completed in Umm Dukhun, Bendisi, and Mukjar localities. These included three (3) veterinary centers, eight (8) water supply systems (including two (2) new hands dug wells and six (6) boreholes rehabilitated), nine (9) community gardens, three (3) markets, three (3) permanent livelihood centers and one (1) peace center.
Results under Output 4: • Forty (40) civil society organizations members were trained on peacebuilding and conflict management. Additionally, three ToTs sessions on conflict sensitivity, and do-no-harm approach training were organized for the civil society groups with 100 attendees including 40 females. The Civil society organizations and CBRMs structure have played effective roles in mitigating tension between the farmers and nomads in the project operational areas. • The project selected 50 youth (40% women) from 10 targeted communities as Peace Ambassadors who played active roles as civil society organizations implementing and practicing peacebuilding activities promoting peace, social cohesion, and human security in their communities. • The project facilitated the engagement between the Peace and Reconciliation Committees in the three targeted localities with the state Peace committee to promote peace and social cohesion. There is an ongoing effort by the project to link the CBRMs (local peace mechanism) to the federal peace institutions and forums.
Results under Output 5: • 6 Field visits embarked to project locations, three joint missions with DCPSF resulted in provision of several finding support achievements of project activities. • Two biannual reports submitted and Four quarterly progress reports to DCPSF. • 7 technical Support visits paid to counterparts.
